@gianm aha, after looking through the codebase I see that making this `multiOutput` would require touching a lot of code. I currently (grudgingly :) ) implemented the workaround with just concatenating stuff, so my need is not so urgent any more.

IMO it would be much better to implement only the long-term solution, as the additional extractionFn option is quite a half-measure. Where could I track the progress of lifting the restriction on string-only values, by the way? I found an assortment of various issues related to that, but no umbrella discussion.

Cool, still üëç

Some comments from the JDBI Google Group, on the `sqlserver-metadata-storage`'s use of the JDBI StatementRewriter class.

[
Using StatementRewriter to rewrite PostgreSQL/MySQL sql syntax to be compatible with Microsoft SqlServer](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/jdbi/aJAouEe1h7I)
- Matthew Hall 
  
  > RegExp is a pretty limited language. With so many vendor-specific behaviors and features, I think you'll find RegExp will only get you so far. If this is just a toy project to ease a database migration, then this may work ok for you, but I wouldn't expect it to be a general-purpose solution that works for everybody.
  > 
  > If you're serious about creating a general purpose tool, I think you'd have more success using EBNF grammar parsers.
- Steven Schlansker 
  
  > You'll also find pretty poor performance with such a rewriter -- the chained replaceAll operations
  > will each have to compile the regex repeatedly.  You might be saved by caching as long as your statements are cacheable -- but if you use something that generates unique SQL statements (such as @BindIn or some custom code) you might shoot yourself in the foot this way.
  > 
  > I think most people simply maintain parallel sets of SQL per database dialect, unfortunately.
  > 
  > None of this is to say it won't work.  Just be aware that you're going to run into serious limitations
  > and this approach probably won't scale well.
Fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3430

In response to the previous [comments](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3421#issuecomment-245048928).

While the current sql transformation might be affected by future sql changes, since Druid's use of SQL is pretty straight forward, the current approach should be sufficient for now.

Also, for better performance I have updated the SQLServerConnector to reuse the sql rewriting patterns.

Hmm, the general idea looks good to me, although if we're going down the road of being more unmappy-happy with ByteBuffers, I think it'd be nice to use a function that does a Files.map and then wraps the result in a ResourceHolder. That way they can be used with try-with-resources, which is cleaner than using Closers imo. Also they could be composed into already existing things we have like ReferenceCountingResourceHolder, if we have some need for refcounted mmapped files.
üëç  with or without the ResourceHolder-returning mmap function. But I do think that would be nice if we are going down this road.

I propose accepting the Closer approach for now and @leventov sending a notice out to the dev mailing list about the potential future need for a more advanced and prettier try-with-resources friendly class with a callout to this PR. So that in the future if the use gets expanded, it will be time to consider the use cases and add a proper class (with proper test framework support)
I'm üëç  on accepting the Closer stuff for this PR. IMO a dev notice isn't super necessary but wouldn't hurt.
@drcrallen @gianm I'm on board with that as well

this is impacting many of our customers and causing inflated hdfs namespace quota issues, so moving to 0.9.2 milestone considering it being a "simple" change.

Anyone else interested in reviewing? We do have two +1s already, but just checking. This has been open for a while and would like to get it in so we can begin building on top of it. If not then I'll merge it in a bit.
I'd like to do a once-over if there is still time.

@drcrallen go for it; although please for @jon-wei's sake I'm hoping we can get this in before other things that might conflict with it (which is basically anything indexing related). He's already done countless rebases :)
if I can't get it done before EOD Friday I forfeit my right to complain about it

There's a trickiness here with ensuring exactly-once ingestion: what happens if 2/3 of the messages are indexed and then a threshold is reached that triggers a disk persist or a publish to deep storage? I think either we would have to do some work to make sure only complete sets are persisted to disks, or we have to track "offset within an offset".

As an aside, @akkapur, what do you mean by "this would allow the user to make fewer calls to Kafka"? The Kafka producer can already batch messages, so it should be able to send those three records as one compressed batch even if they are three different logical messages.

@du00cs, ah, yeah, if "emit" throws an exception then that is an issue with the emitter. Druid assumes that emitting will not throw exceptions, and extensions should assure that is the case by whatever means they choose.

It's a community extension (not maintained by core committers) but patches are definitely welcome if you can fix it yourself! Or you could try pinging people who have worked on it, check the commit history of the extension for details there. IIRC @b-slim was the main original author.

IMO, if we need to have two time columns with basically the same data, that seems like a workaround to an underlying deficiency in the query language. Ideally we could improve the query language to make things work on a single time column.

#3180 was meant to solve (2) without need for a separate column. @kaijianding could you double check if that functionality satisfies your needs? If not, do you think it'd be possible to go down the road of using the __time column directly through some additional options (like @jon-wei had suggested)?

For a sql like
`select * from someDataSource where time > '201608' and time < '201609'`, we can't just say it is in 'yyyyMM' format, '201608' can be '20160801' or '20160801 10' in other sqls, thus IntervalDimFilter can't handle this case even it can support customized format due to we don't know the format in advance.
But we still can do string compare on dimension. @jon-wei

It seems just what I need! Will try this solution, @gianm .
But I think TimeFormatExtractionFn still need to support the formats used in TimestampParser, like posix/nano/ruby/millis/iso.
will take a look at it.

@du00cs checkout this Fix https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3441 assuming one of those exception was the issue.
@gianm thanks very much for the review. can you take a look again ?

@b-slim `emit` also needs handling for the case where the event is an AlertEvent but emitterList is empty. That could totally happen. Rather than log "unknown event type" we should probably either drop the alert or log the alert.

It's possible this case is what caused the original issue in #3389, since @du00cs reported the problem occurred on an alert emit.

@b-slim sure, just took another look and wrote some more comments.

I guess it's challenging to test this in unit tests, so I'm ok if those are missing, but did you test this on an actual kerberized hadoop cluster to confirm it works?

I didn't realize that Druid gets built for both JDK7 and JDK8. Support for JDK7 has been dropped in sketches-core-0.5.0. So if this is a barrier, the latest version we can use is 0.4.1
I was going to work on a new aggregator using latest sketches. This issue makes this plan questionable. Is there a plan to stop building Druid for JDK7?
@AlexanderSaydakov See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/aTGQlnF1KLk
let me test with life cycle stuff.

@gianm good call on this, looks like the taskRunner doesn't call the method annotated with `@LifecycleStart` and i am not sure why it is not called, any hint ? or should i revert it and do it during configure like that we guarantee that the auth is called  ?
hmm, I'm not sure why it wouldn't get called, but I think it's worth trying to figure that out. start is really the right place to do this kind of stuff imo.
i am trying to understand but my guess is that `ExecutorLifecycle` doesn't call extension based registered classes annotated with `start`.
Can you comment more on why the coordinator needs an endpoint?

@AlexanderSaydakov the approach taken with the caffeine (#3028), which also requires Java 8, is to have that particular extension target Java 8 but the rest of Druid target Java 7.

In this case since the datasketches extension already supported Java 7, we probably want to keep supporting it, but it should be ok to make a new datasketches-xxx extension for your new "xxx" aggregator.

@drcrallen @gianm I moved the IndexIO type-specific validation into a method on DimensionHandler and updated parts of the javadocs in the new interfaces, can you take another look?

I'm out of time for review, so I ask one last thing. Please check the output of indexing something like the wiki set or TPCH data, and report back on if they are binary equivalent pre and post this PR, and if they are not, make sure it is well understood why they are not.
